subsection.title: Problem 1. Ideal gas in one and two dimensions

para.p: Use methods of partition functions to find the free energy, energy, pressure, and entropy in one and two dimensions. Compare your result to the 3D case. Express your result for the entropy in terms of the thermal debroglie wavelength.
The Sackur-Tetrode equation which determines the entropy of an ideal mono-atomic gas:

Math.text: S = N * k _ B * delimited-[]@(logarithm@(v _ N / (lambda _ th) ^ 3) + 5 / 2)

para.p:
where
=
v N
/ V N
and
λ th
is the thermal de Broglie wavelength. You should not have to look up numbers here.

Take an ideal gas of Helium at Standard Temperature Pressure (STP) – the volume per particle is
=
v N
/ V N
, and the interparticle spacing is
ℓ 0
, with
=
ℓ 0
v N
/ 1 3
. Determine the inter particle spacing in nm.
Take an ideal gas of Helium at Standard Temperature Pressure (STP). Determine the thermal de Broglie wavelength in nm.
Sackur-Tetrode equation says

Math.text: S = N * k _ B * delimited-[]@(logarithm@(v _ N / (lambda _ th) ^ 3) + 5 / 2)

para.p:
Thus, up to a logarithm (which is never very large), the entropy is of order
⁢ N
k B
. This gives a simple way to estimate entropy of any substance. It is of order the number of particles (times
k B
). Determine
/ S
(
⁢ N
k B
)
for Helium gas at STP.

Often there may be more than one quantum mechanical state with the same energy level
E ℓ
– this is known as degeneracy. A very common source of degeneracy is the quantum mechanical spin. If a particle has spin
1 2
, then it can be in two quantum mechanical spin states, spin up and spin down. If the energy is independent of the spin, then there will be two quantum mechanical states with the same energy level
E ℓ
(one with spin up and one with spin down), and the degeneracy of the energy level is two,
=
g ℓ
2
. In the partition function we sum over states, which is clearly related to the sum over energy levels as follows:

Math.text: (sum _ states)@(e ^ (- (E _ s / k) * T)) = (sum _ (list@(energy - levels, E _ ell)))@(g _ ell * e ^ (- (E _ ell / k) * T))

para.p:
where
g ℓ
is the degeneracy of the
ℓ
-th energy level.
Do problem Blundell, 21.4

Consider HCl gas, which is composed of Hydrogen of mass
m H
and chlorine
⁢ C l

Give a typical distance between the Hydrogen and the Chlorine atoms,
r 0
(in meters). We will assume this distance is fixed.

Use classical considerations, to find the center of mass of the two atoms, and compute the moment of inertia of the two atoms around the center of mass exactly. Assume that the HCl is rotating in the
⁢ x y
plane. Show that

up to terms further suppressed by terms of order
(
/
m H
m
⁢ C l
)
2
. We will keep the leading term only
⁢
m H
r 0
2
in what follows.
The rotational energy levels are

Math.text: epsilon _ rot = delimited-⟨⟩@(L ^ 2 / (2 * I)) = (ell * (ell + 1) * Planck-constant-over-2-pi ^ 2) / (2 * I) = ell * (ell + 1) * Delta

para.p:
where
= Δ

ℏ 2

Δ
in eV and in GHz (i.e.
= f
/ Δ h
). Estimate
⁢
/ Δ k
T
at room temperature, you should find that
/
⁢ k T
Δ
is around 12.

Show that for any system that
C V
is directly determined by the variance in the energy

Recall that the partition function of
N
molecules of H HCl consists of a translational partition function, and a rotational one:

Math.text: Z _ tot similar-to-or-equals ((e * Z _ trans) / N) ^ N * (Z _ rot) ^ N

para.p:
(Where does the factor
(
/ e N
)
N
come from?). Show that

Math.text: C _ V = (3 / 2) * N * k _ B + N * k _ B * delimited-[]@(beta ^ 2 * delimited-⟨⟩@((epsilon _ rot) ^ 2) - beta ^ 2 * (delimited-⟨⟩@(epsilon _ rot)) ^ 2)

para.p: where

Math.text: beta ^ 2 * delimited-⟨⟩@((epsilon _ rot) ^ 2) = (1 / (Z _ rot * beta * Delta)) * ((sum _ (ell = 0)) ^ infinity)@((2 * ell + 1) * (ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta) ^ 2 * e ^ (- ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta))
(1 / (Z _ rot * beta * Delta)) * ((sum _ (ell = 0)) ^ infinity)@((2 * ell + 1) * (ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta) ^ 2 * e ^ (- ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta))
beta * delimited-⟨⟩@(epsilon _ rot) = (1 / (Z _ rot * beta * Delta)) * ((sum _ (ell = 0)) ^ infinity)@((2 * ell + 1) * ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta * e ^ (- ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta))
(1 / (Z _ rot * beta * Delta)) * ((sum _ (ell = 0)) ^ infinity)@((2 * ell + 1) * ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta * e ^ (- ell * (ell + 1) * beta * Delta))

para.p:
Write a program to sum from
= ℓ 0
up to
20
and to compute

Math.text: list@(beta ^ 2 * delimited-⟨⟩@((epsilon _ rot) ^ 2), beta ^ 2 * (delimited-⟨⟩@(epsilon _ rot)) ^ 2, C _ V / k _ B)

para.p: For HCl, use your graph estimate the temperature (in Kelvin) where the classical approximation for the rotational partition function works at the 20% level.
